results.abstract: Russian astronauts Vasily Tsibliyev and Aleksandr Lazutkin, returned from six disastrous months on space station Mir, denounce people who have dwelled publicly on mission's many failures, including Pres Boris N Yeltsin and individual members of press, news conference; Tsibliyev holds crew was unfairly blamed for problems; notes they remained on Mir when they should have abandoned stations at three different times; chronology of events; photo (M)

headline.main: Russian Astronauts Insist Errors, While Human, Were on Earth

results.snippet: So much for the mea culpas.    The two accident-prone astronauts who just ended six disastrous months on the space station Mir used their first public appearance today to denounce everyone -- from President Boris N. Yeltsin to individual members of...
results.lead_paragraph: So much for the mea culpas. The two accident-prone astronauts who just ended six disastrous months on the space station Mir used their first public appearance today to denounce everyone -- from President Boris N. Yeltsin to individual members of the press -- who has dwelled so publicly on the mission's many failures.

results.abstract: Many problems plaguing Russia's space station Mir make it hard to understand why Americans spent most of second half of 20th century convincend that technically superior Soviets were three steps away from conquering the world; John Le Carre said in his novel The Russia House that Soviets' backwardness was its greatest military secret; photo (M)

headline.main: The World; Mir Bobbles Dim the Evil Empire's Aura

results.snippet: FOR months the Russian space station Mir has truly inhabited the twilight zone, performing what usually seems like slapstick comedy until it begins to verge on tragedy. Since a nearly fatal collision in June, when an overloaded supply ship was...
results.lead_paragraph: FOR months the Russian space station Mir has truly inhabited the twilight zone, performing what usually seems like slapstick comedy until it begins to verge on tragedy. Since a nearly fatal collision in June, when an overloaded supply ship was steered into the station's science module instead of into its docking port, every mishap up there has seemed like another episode of ''Lost in Space.'' And before the cosmonauts finally carried out their vital repair mission on Friday, there were a lot of episodes. The 11-year-old computer that runs the world's only manned space station, less powerful than some of the chips now found in cellular telephones, went out of service three times, once when a cosmonaut accidentally disconnected it. There were brownouts, blackouts, losses of oxygen and heat, and a problem with the water. The last commander became so stressed by it all that he developed heart problems.

results.abstract: Many problems plaguing Russia's space station Mir make it hard to understand why Americans spent most of second half of 20th century convincend that technically superior Soviets were three steps away from conquering the world; John Le Carre said in his novel The Russia House that Soviets' backwardness was its greatest military secret; photo (M)
